messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 18, 2017 - October 24, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-25T21:10:57Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-10-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171025-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare (see list below).  There were 1 C-type CME and 2 O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-10-24T15:00Z-18:00Z.  This slight enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-10-24.  

STEREO Ahead IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of the CMEs (that started on 2017-10-18T05:48Z and 2017-10-18T07:48Z) around 2017-10-21T02:30Z (see notification 20171018-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated above the threshold of of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period due to a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-10-11, but declined to background levels on 2017-10-19 and remained nominal for the rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
2017-10-20  23:10:00  23:37:00  23:28:00   M1.1   S10E90 ( 12685 )

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-10-18T05:48Z     ~1439           O              -122/-38               33                          SOHO                              
2017-10-18T07:48Z     ~1468           O              -117/-9                42                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2017-10-18T15:06Z     ~586            C              -119/9                 12                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-10-31T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The active regions visible from the SDO imagery have low magnetic complexity.  There is an active region visible on the east limb of the STEREO A EVUI images that may have the potential to produce solar flares or CMEs.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderated for the upcoming period.  It is currently elevated to Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2017-10-25T06:00Z-09:00Z.  Solar wind speed has reached values of >650 km/s due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.    

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 11, 2017 - October 17, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-18T23:11:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-10-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171018-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period. There were 4 C-type CMEs (see details below).  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods of 2017-10-13T12:00Z to 2017-10-13T15:00Z and 2017-10-13T18:00Z to 2017-10-13T21:00Z. This enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2017-10-11 (see notifications 20171013-AL-001 and 20171013-AL-002). Solar wind speed reached values of ~700 km/s on 2017-10-14.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-10-11 and also on 2017-10-15 with the solar wind speed reaching values of ~500 km/s and ~600 km/s, respectively.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-10-14T12:00Z and remained elevated crossing the threshold several times up to 2017-10-18. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20171014-AL-001, 20171014-AL-002, 20171016-AL-001 and 20171018-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-10-11T15:09Z     ~557            C               139/22                29                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2017-10-13T09:09Z     ~600            C               168/13                19                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2017-10-14T08:24Z     ~652            C               154/14                25                          STEREO A                          
2017-10-17T03:36Z     ~510            C              -110/-11               24                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-10-24T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. STEREO A EUVI images show three active regions, one of them close to disk center around 2017-10-18 which is the source of two fast CMEs on 2017-10-18 heading towards STEREO A that enhanced the flux of 13-100 MeV protons but did not crossed the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV. This active region will rotate on to the Earth facing side of the solar disk in the upcoming week and still has potential for solar flares and coronal mass ejections. Geomagnetic activity may increase around 2017-10-21 due to a high speed stream originating from a small coronal hole close to disk center seen in SDO around 2017-10-18.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CMEs (Spitzer, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-18T16:43:29Z
## Message ID: 20171018-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: O-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-10-18T05:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~1439 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 33 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -122/-38 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-10-18T05:48:00-CME-001

2: O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-10-18T07:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~1468 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 42 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -117/-9 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2017-10-18T07:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact Spitzer and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach Spitzer at 2017-10-19T23:39Z and STEREO A at 2017-10-19T18:12Z (plus minus 7 hours). 


Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CMEs: 2017-10-18T05:48:00-CME-001 and 2017-10-18T07:48:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20171018_080400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 


SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-18T07:16:20Z
## Message ID: 20171018-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to notification with ID 20171016-AL-001.  Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. The GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu on 2017-10-14T12:00Z and continues to be above this threshold, currently at 104,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2017-10-11T18:00Z and reached a speed of about 700 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-10-14T12:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-13T15:40:04Z
## Message ID: 20171013-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2017-10-13T12:00Z to 2017-10-13T15:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-10-11T18:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-10-13T12:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 04, 2017 - October 10, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-11T21:09:46Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-04T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-10-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171011-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant solar flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-10-05T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2017-10-05T21:00-24:00Z, and 2017-10-06T00:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight enhancement in the geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 on 2017-10-04.  Another coronal hole high speed stream arrival was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2017-10-10.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-10-03 that lasted several days with the solar wind speed reaching values of ~600 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-10-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the far side of the solar disk as seen at STEREO A images that could produce solar flares and CMEs.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the coronal hole high speed stream that arrived on 2017-10-10. The geomagnetic Kp index reached values of Kp=5 for the synoptic periods 2017-10-11T06:00Z-09:00Z and 2017-10-11T15:00Z-18:00Z.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 27, 2017 - October 03, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-04T23:27:11Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-09-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-10-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20171004-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no major solar flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=7 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=7 occurred during the synoptic periods 2017-09-28T03:00Z to 2017-09-28T09:00Z. This geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2017-09-27 (see notifications 20170927-AL-001, 20170927-AL-002, 20170928-AL-001 and 20170928-AL-002).  
 
The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-29T08:45Z and remained elevated crossing the threshold several times up to 2017-10-02. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20170929-AL-001, 20170929-AL-002 and 20171001-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-10-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-10-10T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  A couple of active regions currently on the west side of the Earth's facing solar disk have the potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections. Geomagnetic activity may increase in the next few days due to the arrival of a small equatorial coronal hole high speed stream.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-10-01T16:19:50Z
## Message ID: 20171001-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-09-29T08:45Z (see recent notification 20170929-AL-002). For the past two days, the electron flux has been above the threshold or elevated.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-09-27T04:06Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-09-29T08:45:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:
